sn3.10:4.1: Now at that time a large group of people had been put in shackles by King Pasenadi of Kosala—some in ropes, some in manacles, some in chains.
sn3.10:5.1: Then several mendicants got dressed in the morning and, taking their bowls and robes, entered Sāvatthī for alms.
sn3.10:5.2: Then, after the meal, when they returned from alms-round, they went up to the Buddha,
sn3.10:5.3: bowed, sat down to one side,
sn3.10:5.4: and told him what was happening.
sn3.10:6.1: Then, knowing the meaning of this, on that occasion the Buddha recited these verses:
sn3.10:7.1: “The sages say that shackle is not strong
sn3.10:7.2: that’s made of iron, wood, or knots.
sn3.10:7.3: But infatuation with jewels and earrings,
sn3.10:7.4: worry for your partners and children:
sn3.10:8.1: this the sages say is a strong shackle
sn3.10:8.2: that drags you down, tight, hard to escape.
sn3.10:8.3: They cut this too and go forth,
sn3.10:8.4: with no worries, having given up sensual pleasures.”
